short_term_debt.insight: Short-term debt shows rising reliance on rollover funding. Multiple years of elevated YoY spikes (10-13%) indicate stressed liquidity or dependency on working-capital loans, though recent deceleration to 3.7% suggests some stabilization.

long_term_debt.insight: Long-term debt has been increasing steadily at 6-7% annually through Y-2, then plateaued. This pattern suggests capacity expansion or CWIP funding in earlier years. The recent plateau (Y vs Y-1: 0%) may indicate completed projects or constrained credit access.

finance_cost.insight: Finance cost growth has been consistently outpacing debt growth, with YoY increases ranging from 4-8%. The peak growth of 8.51% in Y-2 followed by gradual deceleration indicates rising borrowing costs, interest rate pressure, or shift toward more expensive debt instruments during the growth phase.

analysis_narrative: Total debt has grown at 12% CAGR over the last 5 years, materially faster than EBITDA, which grew at 6%.
Debt-to-EBITDA of 4.3 and D/E of 2.1 are above comfortable levels, indicating elevated leverage.
Over 50% of debt matures within 1 year, creating meaningful refinancing risk.
Floating-rate debt represents 65% of total borrowing, exposing the company to interest rate volatility.

red_flags.title: Stressed leverage and weak coverage
red_flags.detail: Debt-to-EBITDA above 4x and ICR below 2x suggest heightened default risk if earnings weaken.

red_flags.title: Refinancing and rate risk
red_flags.detail: More than half of debt is short-term and 65% is floating-rate, increasing rollover and interest cost risk.

positive_points: Some LT debt appears to be funding CWIP, indicating growth-oriented capex.
No clear covenant breach identified, though headroom is narrowing.
